bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to G. Glenwood Clark, April 2, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Clark that Blossom is writing a story about Susie, the Apache girl who worked in her father's household. He shares confidential information about Blossom's financial hardship, and says that he believes Reed's daughter should have the rights to this story, which Clark has been interested in publishing himself.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to G. Glenwood Clark, April 2, 1952
div1.opener:
April 2, 1952
Mr. G. Glenwood Clark
110 North Boundary Street
Williamsburg, Virginia
My dear Mr. Clark:
div1.p:
You wrote me some time ago about a young Indian girl cared for by
Walter Reed. I wrote that I had no information about this of my
own. I wrote to Blossom Reed, Walter Reed's daughter and find that
she is herself writing a story about that at this very moment.

Confidentially, the financial circumstances of Walter Reed's daughter
leave much to be desired. She has her home at Blue Ridge Summit but
receives only an anuity of $85 a month. Therefore she has to rent rooms
to soldiers and their wives from a nearby camp. There has been a
great reduction apparently in the opportunities for renting these
rooms and that has made her decide to write one or two stories about
her father. I am sure you can appreciate her situation. She implied
from her letter that she had already been working on this story
about the “Indian woman” before she heard from me about you. I am
sure you will agree that the daughter or son of Walter Reed has the
first right to such a story.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
